channel.title: The decimal Type :: Data Structures in C#
channel.description: The decimal Type A decimal is a structure representing a floating-point decimal number. The main difference between a decimal and a float or a double is that a decimal can store any value that can be written using no more than 28 decimal digits, a decimal point, and optionally a ‘-’, without rounding. For example, the value 0.1 cannot be stored exactly in either a float or a double because its binary representation is infinite (0.
